abstract: Bank of America and the Justice Department are still far apart on a mortgage settlement. | Argentina has found a relentless foe in Paul E. Singer. | G.E.’s Synchrony Financial begins trading on Thursday. | BNP Paribas posts a record quarterly loss.
snippet: Bank of America and the Justice Department are still far apart on a mortgage settlement. | Argentina has found a relentless foe in Paul E. Singer. | G.E.’s Synchrony Financial begins trading on Thursday. | BNP Paribas posts a record quarterly loss...
lead_paragraph: Bank of America and federal prosecutors have accelerated their negotiations to resolve an investigation into the bank’s sale of troubled mortgage securities before the financial crisis, Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. But the two sides remain far apart on crucial issues, and a settlement remained elusive late on Wednesday, even after the bank raised its offer.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Bank of America and U.S. Far Apart on Deal

abstract: In a new report released on Thursday, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said fees for customers who overdraw their accounts continue to pile up, particularly among young people.
snippet: In a new report released on Thursday, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said fees for customers who overdraw their accounts continue to pile up, particularly among young people.
lead_paragraph: Four years after federal regulators passed new rules aimed at curbing overdraft fees, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is still finding problems with the high fees that banks charge customers when they overdraw their accounts.

headline.main: Regulators Still Find Problems in Overdraft Fees
